Posts.Title: Resection suefly suefly

Posts.Content: suefly wrote: I was informed by the plastic surgeon of how important it is to quit smoking (and all nicotine products ..so no patch ect.) before reconstruction surgery.  I know this is the dumbest thing I can do for my health anyways, but trying to quit at such a stressful time is going to be quite the challenge. I am having a double masectomy with sentinal node biopsy. This is probably my chance to kick the habit for good. If anyone has had to deal with this quitting smoking quick thing, and has any tips, please share. Dx 11/8/2010, DCIS, 2cm, Stage I, Grade 2, 0/1 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Quitting smoking before surgery..STRESS! suefly suefly

Posts.Content: Jan 21, 2011 08:28AM suefly wrote: Thanks BarbaraA! I checked it out...some good advice!
Posts.Title: Quitting smoking before surgery..STRESS! suefly suefly

Posts.Content: Jan 30, 2011 01:15AM suefly wrote: Its kind of funny. I feel like I am doing the same...its like the nesting thing when I was getting ready to have my kids..only not as much fun.
Posts.Title: February 2011 Mastectomy texasrose361 TinaT

Posts.Content: Feb 4, 2011 02:39PM suefly wrote: That sounds very encouraging!! I been getting a little nervous here and there with only 4 days left...and have stayed nicotine free for a week...all set with that stuff. Its good so hear your doing well.
Posts.Title: February 2011 Mastectomy texasrose361 TinaT

Posts.Content: Feb 15, 2011 11:39PM suefly wrote: I did the same thing..felt like nesting. I had to go out and get anything that I wouldnt want anyone to have to get for me, and tried to organize the house (but didnt really have enough time). Now after surgery , on Feb 8, I am happy that I can do much more than I expected. However, my head seems to be a bit fuzzy. I wont lie, the pain that I had was the worst I could imagine, and I still have constant pain and pressure, with intermittent sharp jabs, but I am functioning with it. I cant wait to get rid of the drains.And the other thing I have been dealing with is severe abdominal bloating. My bowels are functioning fine though, so from what i can get from "googling" it, it is rather common to have this fluid shift after surgery. Its not painful, just annoying. It could be much worse. Still waiting for pathology though. I had bmx and sentinal node biopsy.
Posts.Title: February 2011 Mastectomy texasrose361 TinaT

Posts.Content: Feb 21, 2011 03:15PM suefly wrote: My BMX with sentinal node biopsy was on the 8th...I was surprised at how much I was able to do when I got home 4 days later..the pain the first three days was awful. I have been recovering well, but the past few days I started to get really stiff in the back and am getting a bad "creepy-crawlly" feeling in my chest..I don't know how else to explain it. I am ready to rip the last two out of four drains out.but I should be able to have them out tomorrow. What makes it all better is that the patholgy came back good...negative node, and no cancer at the margins ect... this will be over once I heal from this!!! Thinking of everyone else who had surgery this month, and of those who have it much worse. My prayers are with you all.
Posts.Title: February 2011 Mastectomy texasrose361 TinaT

Posts.Content: Jan 30, 2011 01:12AM suefly wrote: Having skin sparing bilateral masectomy and sentinal node biopsy, with immediate reconstruction (tissue expanders) on Feb 8th. Have to quit smoking tomorrow..yikes!! I keep forgetting to ask the Dr. what type of bra or whatever I need to wear right after. Any suggestions?
Posts.Title: February 2011 Mastectomy texasrose361 TinaT

Posts.Content: Mar 29, 2011 01:28PM suefly wrote: Thanks Tina. I bet part of the problem is living in New England! We had some beautiful spring-like wx a week and a half ago and I got new sneakers and was out walking my old route outside..just slower. But that only lasted two days. I kept up with inside exercise , using my treadmill on a steep incline..but it just doesnt energize me the same way. This past weekend I spent two days walking around Boston with friends and felt great..I  think maybe I am just paying for it after. I guess I just wanted to be reassured that I am not the only one who isnt back to 100%. I have never been throught anything so intense before, so its strange to get used to not keeping up the same pace. Thanks, glad you are doing well. Maybe I should take a trip to somewhere warm!
Posts.Title: February 2011 Mastectomy texasrose361 TinaT

Posts.Content: Jan 20, 2011 11:36PM suefly wrote: Bilat. masectomy sometime in early Feb. , waiting for the date.
Posts.Title: February 2011 Mastectomy texasrose361 TinaT

Posts.Content: Feb 24, 2011 05:53AM suefly wrote: I get all kinds of weird sensations..some burning, some pulling, and some that feel like I'm cold, but just in my chest..again, its kind of a creepy crawlly feeling. I would say that mostly I'm just uncomfortable two weeks after surgery, but not having a lot of pain..just the occasional jabs that last for a few minutes. Its good to be off any pain meds. I have been getting around and doing stuff, but I am a little frustrated at how tired I am feeling still..its more of a sleepy feeling than a physical thing.I just never really required a lot of sleep before. How are other people feeling a few weeks post-op?
Posts.Title: February 2011 Mastectomy texasrose361 TinaT

Posts.Content: Feb 24, 2011 01:59PM suefly wrote: ibcmets, Thanks for the info..wow, a week for every hour? My surgery was 7 to 8 hours, I guess I have a good exuse then.Hope you doing ok.
Posts.Title: February 2011 Mastectomy texasrose361 TinaT

Posts.Content: Mar 29, 2011 11:44AM suefly wrote: Anyone in the February Masectomy group still having a lot of fatigue? I have good days and then days that I just dont seem to have motivation to do anything. I have been working out and going to physical therapy. I am wondering when this will go away. Its been almost seven weeks since surgery. Just wondering if anyone else is in the same boat, then I will feel more normal.

Does anyone know if I need to be concerned about this? When I google stuff I can only find info on either/or and not when these two are found together. The surgeon didn't seem concerned, and I don't have an appointment with an onocologist yet...working on that. From what I see ALH is a marker for bilateral ILC?
